explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: According to Chemical Dictionary (1994), the hydrate form can be dehydrated by heating (3-hydrate when heated at 30degC, 1-hydrate at 110degC, anhydride at 250degC). The kick-off temperature is considered to exceed 75degC.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water (water solubility: 22.05g/100g (25degC) (anhydride equivalent), Lide (84th, 2003))

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being inorganic compounds containing oxygen

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 960mg/kg (EHC 200 (1998)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. The substance can be "Not classified" or classified into "Category 5" based on the available data (rat LD50 of >2,000mg/kg (dermal route)) (RTECS (2006)). If the study is conducted in accordance with OECD Guideline which specifies the upper limit at 2,000mg/kg, it is reasonable to consider the substance to be "Not classified" unless "there arises an urgent concern to human health," because no study is expected to be conducted with larger doses. However, "classification is not possible" since, in this study report, only numerical results are provided and study details are not available (the priority rating for the study is 2).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (ICSC (2001)): "Causes redness and pain" (though the severity of the effects is unknown). The substance is thus considered a skin irritant.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (ICSC (2001)): "Causes pain, redness and dimness of sight" (though the severity of the effects is unknown). Although classified into Category 2A-2B, the substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory Sensitizer: Classification not possible Skin Sensitizer: Category 1
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available Skin sensitizer: Due to the fact that the substance is classified into "Group 2" (as copper and its compounds) by the Japan Society for Occupational Health, and a "Skin Sensitizing Substance" (as copper) by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy (2004).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), described in NTP DB (Access on July, 2006), ATSDR (2004) and EHC 200 (1998).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible based on expert judgment in the absence of existing classification (though some toxicity data are available).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on the evidence of malformation and adverse effects on postnatal development of pups, described in ATSDR (2004), EHC 200 (1998) and CERI Hazard Data 2001-59 (2002) (though no data are available regarding parental animals).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (blood system, liver, nervous system, kidneys, respiratory organs)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "symptoms including vomiting, lethargy, acute hemolytic anemia, renal and liver damage, neurotoxicity, increased blood pressure and respiratory rates" (EHC 200 (1998)), "deaths, probably due to central nervous system depression and hepatic and renal failure, have also been reported," "renal tubular damage was observed" (ATSDR (2004)), and the evidence from animal studies: "acute inflammatory changes were evident in the lungs" (EHC 200 (1998)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (blood system, kidneys, respiratory organs) Category 2 (liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "hemolytic anemia was noted," "pathological alterations include pulmonary inflammation, formation of granulomas, fibrohyaline nodules, desquamation of macrophages, and progression of diffuse fibrosis" (ATSDR (2004)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies: "protein droplets in the cytoplasm of cells in the proximal convoluted tubules," "in the kidneys, cytoplasmic protein droplets were evident, and hematological changes indicative of microcytic anemia were observed " (EHC 200 (1998)), "the earliest symptoms of hepatotoxicity are increases in serum chemistry enzymes, particularly alanine aminotransferase" (ATSDR (2004)), "repeated or prolonged exposure to aerosols may result in lung damage" (ICSC (J) (2001)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (kidneys) and Category 2 (liver).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours LC50=0.00272mg/L of the crustacea (Ceriodaphnia) (ECETOC TR91, 2003).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.
